cleaned_text: produced by more than [200 species](/wiki/List_of_psilocybin_mushroom_species) of [fungi](/wiki/Fungus). The most potent are members of such [P. azurescens](/wiki/Psilocybe_azurescens), [P. semilanceata](/wiki/Psilocybe_semilanceata), and [P. cyanescens](/wiki/Psilocybe_cyanescens), but psilocybin has been isolated from about a dozen other genera. Psilocybin is itself biologically inactive but is quickly converted by the body to [psilocin](/wiki/Psilocin), which has mind-altering effects similar, in some aspects, to those of [lysergic acid diethylamide](/wiki/LSD) (LSD), [mescaline](/wiki/Mescaline), and [dimethyltryptamine](/wiki/N,N-Dimethyltryptamine) (DMT). In general, the effects include [euphoria](/wiki/Euphoria), visual and mental [hallucinations](/wiki/Hallucination), changes in perception, distorted [sense of time](/wiki/Time_perception), and perceived spiritual experiences. It can also cause adverse reactions such as [nausea](/wiki/Nausea) and [panic attacks](/wiki/Panic_attack). Imagery found on [cave paintings](/wiki/Cave_painting) and [rock art](/wiki/Rock_art) of modern-day Spain and Algeria suggests that human use of [psilocybin mushrooms](/wiki/Psilocybin_mushroom) predates recorded history. In [Mesoamerica](/wiki/Mesoamerica), the mushrooms had long been consumed in spiritual and [divinatory](/wiki/Divination) ceremonies before Spanish chroniclers first documented their use in the sixteenth century. In 1958, the Swiss chemist [Albert Hofmann](/wiki/Albert_Hofmann) isolated psilocybin and psilocin from the mushroom Hofmann's employer [Sandoz](/wiki/Sandoz) marketed and sold pure psilocybin to physicians and clinicians worldwide for use in [psychedelic therapy](/wiki/Psychedelic_therapy). Although the increasingly restrictive drug laws of the [1960s](/wiki/Single_Convention_on_Narcotic_Drugs) and the [1970s](/wiki/Convention_on_Psychotropic_Substances) curbed scientific research into the effects of psilocybin and other hallucinogens, its popularity as an [entheogen](/wiki/Entheogen) (spirituality-enhancing agent) grew in the next decade, owing largely to the increased availability of information on how to cultivate psilocybin mushrooms. The intensity and duration of the effects of psilocybin are variable, depending on species or [cultivar](/wiki/Cultivar) of mushrooms, dosage, individual physiology, and [set and setting](/wiki/Set_and_setting), as was shown in experiments led by [Timothy Leary](/wiki/Timothy_Leary) at [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University) in the early 1960s. Once ingested, psilocybin is rapidly metabolized to psilocin, which then acts on [serotonin receptors](/wiki/5-HT_receptor) in the brain. The mind-altering effects of psilocybin typically last from two to six hours, although to individuals under the influence of psilocybin, the effects may seem to last much longer, since the drug can distort the perception of time. Possession of psilocybin-containing mushrooms [has been outlawed](/wiki/Legal_status_of_psilocybin_mushrooms) in most countries, and psilocybin has been classified as a [Schedule I controlled substance](/wiki/Convention_on_Psychotropic_Substances#Schedule_I) under the 1971 United Nations [Convention on Psychotropic Substances](/wiki/Convention_on_Psychotropic_Substances). Effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=1)] The effects of psilocybin are highly variable and depend on the mindset and environment in which the user has the experience, factors commonly referred to as [set and setting](/wiki/Set_and_setting). In the early 1960s, [Timothy Leary](/wiki/Timothy_Leary) and colleagues at Harvard University investigated the role of set and setting on the effects of psilocybin. They administered the drug to 175 volunteers from various backgrounds in an environment intended to be similar to a comfortable living room. 98 of the subjects were given questionnaires to assess their experiences and the contribution of background and situational factors. Individuals who had experience with psilocybin prior to the study reported more pleasant experiences than those for whom the drug was novel. Group size, dosage, preparation, and expectancy were important determinants of the drug response. In general, those in groups of more than eight felt that the groups were less supportive, and their experiences less pleasant. Conversely, smaller groups (fewer than six) were seen as more supportive and reported more positive reactions to the drug in those groups. Leary and colleagues proposed that psilocybin heightens suggestibility, making an individual more receptive to interpersonal interactions and environmental stimuli. [[6]](#cite_note-Leary1963-7) These findings were affirmed in a later review by Jos ten Berge (1999), who concluded that dosage, set, and setting were fundamental factors in determining the outcome of experiments that tested the effects of psychedelic drugs on artists' creativity. [[7]](#cite_note-Berge1999-8) After ingesting psilocybin, a wide range of subjective effects may be experienced: feelings of disorientation, lethargy, giddiness, [euphoria](/wiki/Euphoria), joy, and [depression](/wiki/Depression_(mood)). In one study, 31% of volunteers given a high dose reported feelings of significant fear and 17% experienced transient [paranoia](/wiki/Paranoia). [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) In studies at [Johns Hopkins](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University) among those given a moderate dose (but still enough to "give a high probability of a profound and beneficial experience"), negative experiences were rare, whereas one-third of those given a high dose experienced anxiety or paranoia. [[9]](#cite_note-10) [[10]](#cite_note-Hopkins2011-11) Low doses can induce hallucinatory effects. [Closed-eye hallucinations](/wiki/Closed-eye_hallucination) may occur, where the affected individual sees multicolored geometric shapes and vivid imaginative sequences. [[11]](#cite_note-Hasler2004-12) Some individuals report [synesthesia](/wiki/Synesthesia), such as tactile sensations when viewing colors. [[12]](#cite_note-Ballesteros_2006-13): 175 At higher doses, psilocybin can lead to "intensification of [affective](/wiki/Affect_(psychology)) responses, enhanced ability for introspection, [regression](/wiki/Regression_(psychology)) to primitive and childlike thinking, and activation of vivid memory traces with pronounced emotional undertones". [[13]](#cite_note-Studerus2011-14) Open-eye visual [hallucinations](/wiki/Hallucination) are common, and may be very detailed although [rarely confused with reality.](/wiki/Pseudohallucination) [[11]](#cite_note-Hasler2004-12) A 2011 [prospective study](/wiki/Prospective_cohort) by [Roland R. Griffiths](/wiki/Roland_R._Griffiths) and colleagues suggests that a single high dosage of psilocybin can cause long-term changes in the [personality](/wiki/Personality_psychology) of its users. About half of the study participants—described as healthy, "spiritually active", and many possessing [postgraduate degrees](/wiki/Postgraduate_diploma)—showed an increase in the personality dimension of [openness](/wiki/Openness_to_experience) (assessed using the [Revised NEO Personality Inventory](/wiki/Revised_NEO_Personality_Inventory)), and this positive effect was apparent more than a year after the psilocybin session. According to the study authors, the finding is significant because "no study has prospectively demonstrated personality change in healthy adults after an experimentally manipulated discrete event". [[14]](#cite_note-Maclean2011-15) A further study by Griffiths in 2017 found that doses of 20 to 30mg/70kg psilocybin inducing mystical-type experiences brought more lasting changes to traits including altruism, gratitude, forgiveness and feeling close to others when they were combined with a regular [meditation](/wiki/Meditation) practice and an extensive spiritual practice support program. [[15]](#cite_note-Griffiths2017-16) [[16]](#cite_note-17) Although other researchers have described instances of psychedelic drug usage leading to new psychological understandings and personal insights, [[17]](#cite_note-Frecska2006-18) it is not known whether these experimental results can be generalized to larger populations. [[14]](#cite_note-Maclean2011-15) Physical effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=2)] Common (25%); and [dysmetria](/wiki/Dysmetria) (16%) (inability to properly direct or limit motions). [[b]](#cite_note-20) The temporary increases in blood pressure caused by the drug can be a risk factor for users with pre-existing hypertension. [[11]](#cite_note-Hasler2004-12) These qualitative somatic effects caused by psilocybin have been corroborated by several early clinical studies. [[19]](#cite_note-21) A 2005 magazine survey of clubgoers in the UK found that nausea or vomiting was experienced by over a quarter of those who had used psilocybin mushrooms in the last year, although this effect is caused by the mushroom rather than psilocybin itself. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) In one study, administration of gradually increasing dosages of psilocybin daily for 21 days had no measurable effect on [electrolyte](/wiki/Electrolyte) levels, [blood sugar](/wiki/Blood_sugar) distortions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=3)] Psilocybin is known to strongly influence the subjective experience of the [passage of time](/wiki/Time_perception). [[20]](#cite_note-Heimann1994-22) Users often feel as if time is slowed down, resulting in the perception that "minutes appear to be hours" or "time is standing still". [[21]](#cite_note-Wittmann2007-23) Studies have demonstrated that psilocybin significantly impairs subjects' ability to gauge time intervals longer than 2.5 seconds, impairs their ability to synchronize to inter-beat intervals longer than 2 seconds, and reduces their preferred [tapping rate](/wiki/Tapping_rate). [[21]](#cite_note-Wittmann2007-23) [[22]](#cite_note-Wackermann2008-24) These results are consistent with the drug's role in affecting [prefrontal cortex](/wiki/Prefrontal_cortex) activity, [[23]](#cite_note-Carter2005-25) and the role that the prefrontal cortex is known to play in time perception. [[24]](#cite_note-Harrington1999-26) However, the neurochemical basis of psilocybin's effects on the perception of time are not known with certainty. [[25]](#cite_note-Coull2011-27) Users having a pleasant experience can feel a sense of connection to others, nature, and the universe; other perceptions and emotions are also often intensified. Users having an unpleasant experience (a " [bad trip](/wiki/Bad_trip)") describe a reaction accompanied by fear, other unpleasant feelings, and occasionally by dangerous behavior. In general, the phrase "bad trip" is used to describe a reaction that is characterized primarily by fear or other unpleasant emotions, not just transitory experience of such feelings. A variety of factors may contribute to a psilocybin user experiencing a bad trip, including "tripping" during an emotional or physical low or in a non-supportive environment (see: [set and setting](/wiki/Set_and_setting)). Ingesting psilocybin in combination with other drugs, including alcohol, can also increase the likelihood of a bad trip. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) [[26]](#cite_note-Attema2007-28) Other than the duration of the experience, the effects of psilocybin are similar to comparable dosages of [lysergic acid diethylamide](/wiki/LSD) (LSD) or mescaline. Stafford](/wiki/Peter_Stafford) noted, "The psilocybin experience seems to be warmer, not as forceful and less isolating. It tends to build connections between people, who are generally much more in communication than when they use LSD." [[27]](#cite_note-Stafford1992-29): 273 Group perceptions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=4)] Through insights" [[28]](#cite_note-30) and the psycho-social effects of psilocybin, it can be seen in many traditional societies that powerful mind-active substances such as psilocybin are regularly "consumed ritually for therapeutic purposes or for transcending normal, everyday reality". [[29]](#cite_note-Batchelder_2001-31) Positive effects that psilocybin has on individuals can be observed by taking on an anthropological approach and moving away from the Western bio-medical society; this is aided by the studies done by Leary. [[30]](#cite_note-32) Within certain traditional societies where the use of psilocybin is frequent for shamanic healing rituals, group collectives praise their guide, healer and shaman for helping alleviate them of pains, aches and hurt. They do this through a group ritual practice where participants, or just the guide, ingests psilocybin to help extract any " [toxic psychic residues or sorcerous implants](https://go.gale.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA76445692&sid=googleScholar&v=2.1&it=r&linkaccess=abs&issn=15254283&p=AONE&sw=w&userGroupName=anon%7E15bc39a7)" [[29]](#cite_note-Batchelder_2001-31) found in one's body. Group therapies using classic psychedelics are becoming more commonly used in the Western world in clinical practice. This may continue to grow as long providing the evidence remains indicative of safety and efficacy. [[31]](#cite_note-33) In social sense, the group is shaped by their experiences surrounding psilocybin and how they view the plant collectively. As mentioned in the anthropology article, [[29]](#cite_note-Batchelder_2001-31) the group partakes in a "journey" together, thus adding to the spiritual, social body, where roles, hierarchies and gender are subjectively understood. [[29]](#cite_note-Batchelder_2001-31) Mystical experiences[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=5)] Psilocybin mushrooms have been and continue to be used in indigenous New World cultures in religious, [divinatory](/wiki/Divination), or [spiritual](/wiki/Spirituality) contexts. Reflecting the meaning of the word [entheogen](/wiki/Entheogen) ("the god within"), the mushrooms are revered as powerful spiritual [sacraments](/wiki/Sacrament) that provide access to sacred worlds. Typically used in small group community settings, they enhance [group cohesion](/wiki/Group_cohesiveness) and reaffirm traditional values. [[32]](#cite_note-Winkelman2007-34) [Terence McKenna](/wiki/Terence_McKenna) documented the worldwide practices of psilocybin mushroom usage as part of a cultural [ethos](/wiki/Ethos) relating to the Earth and mysteries of nature, and suggested that mushrooms enhanced [self-awareness](/wiki/Self-awareness) and a sense of contact with a "Transcendent Other"—reflecting a deeper understanding of our connectedness with nature. [[33]](#cite_note-McKenna1992-35) Psychedelic drugs can induce states of [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness) that have lasting personal meaning and spiritual significance in individuals who are religious or spiritually inclined; these states are called [mystical experiences](/wiki/Mystical_experience). Some scholars have proposed that many of the qualities of a drug-induced mystical experience are indistinguishable from mystical experiences achieved through [non-drug techniques](/wiki/Religious_experience#Causes_of_religious_experiences), such as meditation or [holotropic breathwork](/wiki/Holotropic_breathwork). [[34]](#cite_note-James1997-36) [[35]](#cite_note-Metzner1998-37) In the 1960s, [Walter Pahnke](/wiki/Walter_Pahnke) and colleagues systematically evaluated mystical experiences (which they called "mystical consciousness") by categorizing their common features. These categories, according to Pahnke, "describe the core of a universal psychological experience, free from culturally determined philosophical or theological interpretations", and allow researchers to assess mystical experiences on a qualitative, numerical scale. [[36]](#cite_note-Pahnke1969-38) In the 1962 [Marsh Chapel Experiment](/wiki/Marsh_Chapel_Experiment), which was run by Pahnke at the [Harvard Divinity School](/wiki/Harvard_Divinity_School) under the supervision of Timothy Leary, [[37]](#cite_note-Pahnke1966-39) almost all of the graduate degree [divinity](/wiki/Seminary) student volunteers who received psilocybin reported profound religious experiences. [[38]](#cite_note-Griffiths2008-40) One of the participants was religious scholar [Huston Smith](/wiki/Huston_Smith), author of several textbooks on [comparative religion](/wiki/Comparative_religion); he later described his experience as "the most powerful cosmic homecoming I have ever experienced." [[39]](#cite_note-Smith2000-41) In a 25-year followup to the experiment, all of the subjects given psilocybin described their experience as having elements of "a genuine mystical nature and characterized it as one of the high points of their spiritual life". [[40]](#cite_note-Doblin_1991-42): 13 Psychedelic researcher [Rick Doblin](/wiki/Rick_Doblin) considered the study partially flawed due to incorrect implementation of the [double-blind](/wiki/Double-blind) procedure, and several imprecise questions in the mystical experience questionnaire. Nevertheless, he said that the study cast "a considerable doubt on the assertion that mystical experiences catalyzed by drugs are in any way inferior to non-drug mystical experiences in both their immediate content and long-term effects". [[40]](#cite_note-Doblin_1991-42): 24 This sentiment was echoed by psychiatrist William A. Richards, who in a 2007 review stated "[psychedelic] mushroom use may constitute one technology for evoking revelatory experiences that are similar, if not identical, to those that occur through so-called spontaneous alterations of brain chemistry." [[41]](#cite_note-Richards2008-43) A group of researchers from [Johns Hopkins School of Medicine](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_School_of_Medicine) led by [Roland Griffiths](/wiki/Roland_Griffiths) conducted a study to assess the immediate and long-term psychological effects of the psilocybin experience, using a modified version of the mystical experience questionnaire and a rigorous double-blind procedure. [[42]](#cite_note-Griffiths2006-44) When asked in an interview about the similarity of his work with Leary's, Griffiths explained the difference: "We are conducting rigorous, systematic research with psilocybin under carefully monitored conditions, a route which Dr. Leary abandoned in the early 1960s." [[43]](#cite_note-JHMed:_Griffiths_Interview-45) The [National Institute of Drug Abuse](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Drug_Abuse)-funded study, published in 2006, has been praised by experts for the soundness of its experimental design. [[c]](#cite_note-46) In the experiment, 36 volunteers without prior experience with hallucinogens were given psilocybin and [methylphenidate](/wiki/Methylphenidate) (Ritalin) in separate sessions; methylphenidate sessions served as a [control](/wiki/Scientific_control) and psychoactive [placebo](/wiki/Placebo). The degree of mystical experience was measured using a questionnaire developed by Ralph W. Hood; [[44]](#cite_note-Hood1975-47) 61% of subjects reported a "complete mystical experience" after their psilocybin session, while only 13% reported such an outcome after their experience with methylphenidate. Two months after taking psilocybin, 79% of the participants reported moderately to greatly increased [life satisfaction](/wiki/Life_satisfaction) and sense of well-being. About 36% of participants also had a strong to extreme "experience of fear" or [dysphoria](/wiki/Dysphoria) (i.e., a "bad trip") at some point during the psilocybin session (which was not reported by any subject during the methylphenidate session); about one-third of these (13% of the total) reported that this dysphoria dominated the entire session. These negative effects were reported to be easily managed by the researchers and did not have a lasting negative effect on the subject's sense of well-being. [[45]](#cite_note-urlMedical_News:_Psilocybin_Viewed_as_Therapy_or_Research_Tool_-_in_Psychiatry,_Addictions_from_MedPage_Today-48) A follow-up study conducted 14 months after the original psilocybin session confirmed that participants continued to attribute deep personal meaning to the experience. Almost one-third of the subjects reported that the experience was the single most meaningful or spiritually significant event of their lives, and over two-thirds reported it among their five most spiritually significant events. About two-thirds indicated that the experience increased their sense of well-being or life satisfaction. [[38]](#cite_note-Griffiths2008-40) Even after 14 months, those who reported mystical experiences scored on average 4 percentage points higher on the personality trait of [Openness/Intellect](/wiki/Openness_to_experience); personality traits are normally stable across the lifespan for adults. Likewise, in a recent (2010) web-based questionnaire study designed to investigate user perceptions of the benefits and harms of hallucinogenic drug use, 60% of the 503 psilocybin users reported that their use of psilocybin had a long-term positive impact on their sense of well-being. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) [[46]](#cite_note-CarhartHarris2010-49) While many recent studies have concluded that psilocybin can cause mystical-type experiences having substantial and sustained personal meaning and spiritual significance, not all the medical community agree. [Paul R. McHugh](/wiki/Paul_R._McHugh), formerly director of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Science at Johns Hopkins, responded as follows in a book review: "The unmentioned fact in The Harvard Psychedelic Club is that LSD, psilocybin, mescaline, and the like produce not a "higher consciousness" but rather a particular kind of "lower consciousness" known well to psychiatrists and Available forms[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=6)] Although psilocybin may be prepared synthetically, outside of the research setting it is not typically used in this form. The psilocybin present in certain species of mushrooms can be ingested in several ways: by consuming fresh or dried fruit bodies, by preparing an [herbal tea](/wiki/Herbal_tea), or by combining with other foods to mask the bitter taste. [[48]](#cite_note-EMCDDA-51) In rare cases people have injected mushroom extracts [intravenously](/wiki/Intravenous). [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) Adverse effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=7)] Most of the comparatively few fatal incidents reported in the literature that are associated with psychedelic mushroom usage involve the simultaneous use of other drugs, especially [alcohol](/wiki/Ethanol). Probably the most common cause of hospital admissions resulting from psychedelic mushroom usage involves "bad trips" or [panic reactions](/wiki/Panic_attack), in which affected individuals become extremely anxious, confused, agitated, or disoriented. Accidents, [self-injury](/wiki/Self-harm), or [suicide](/wiki/Suicide) attempts can result from serious cases of acute [psychotic episodes](/wiki/Psychosis). [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) Although no studies have linked psilocybin with [birth defects](/wiki/Birth_defects), [[49]](#cite_note-Pagliaro2012-52) it is recommended that pregnant women avoid its usage. [[50]](#cite_note-Schaefer2001-53) Toxicity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=8)] Data are sparse, but in the decade leading up to 2020, an increasing number of psilocybin mushroom overdoses were recorded. Nonetheless, the number of events requiring hospitalization remain rare, and overdoses are generally mild and self-limiting. A review regarding the management of psychedelic overdoses suggested that psilocybin related overdose management should prioritize managing the immediate adverse effects, such as anxiety and paranoia, rather than specific pharmacological interventions, as its physiological toxicity tends to be rather limited. [[51]](#cite_note-Reinert2020-54) One analysis of mushrooms used by people hospitalized from psilocybin poisoning found high concentrations of [phenethylamine](/wiki/Phenethylamine) (PEA), which has also been detected in the urine of people who have used psilocybin mushrooms. It is hypothesized that PEA may intensify the effect of psilocybin poisoning. [[51]](#cite_note-Reinert2020-54) In rats, the [median lethal dose](/wiki/Median_lethal_dose) (LD50) when administered orally is 280 milligrams per kilogram (mg/kg), approximately one and a half times that of [caffeine](/wiki/Caffeine). When administered [intravenously](/wiki/Intravenous_injection) in rabbits, psilocybin's LD50 is approximately 12.5 mg/kg. [[52]](#cite_note-Merck13th-55) comprises approximately 1% of the weight of Psilocybe cubensis mushrooms, and so nearly 1.7 kilograms (3.7 lb) of dried mushrooms, or 17 kilograms (37 lb) of fresh mushrooms, would be required for a 60-kilogram (130 lb) person to reach the 280 mg/kg LD50 value of rats. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) Based on the results of animal studies, the [lethal dose](/wiki/Lethal_dose) of psilocybin has been extrapolated to be 6 grams, 1000 times greater than the [effective dose](/wiki/Effective_dose_(pharmacology)) of 6 milligrams. [[53]](#cite_note-Gable2004-56) The [Registry of Toxic Effects of Chemical Substances](/wiki/Registry_of_Toxic_Effects_of_Chemical_Substances) assigns psilocybin a relatively high [therapeutic index](/wiki/Therapeutic_index) of 641 (higher values correspond to a better safety profile); for comparison, the therapeutic indices of [aspirin](/wiki/Aspirin) and [nicotine](/wiki/Nicotine) are 199 and 21, respectively. [[54]](#cite_note-Strassman2008-57) The lethal dose from psilocybin toxicity alone is unknown, and has rarely been documented—as of 2011 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit), only two cases attributed to overdosing on hallucinogenic mushrooms (without concurrent use of other drugs) have been reported in the scientific literature and may involve other factors aside from psilocybin. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) [[d]](#cite_note-60) Psychiatric[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=9)] Panic reactions can occur after consumption of psilocybin-containing mushrooms, especially if the ingestion is accidental or otherwise unexpected. Reactions characterized by violent behavior, suicidal thoughts, [[57]](#cite_note-Peden1982-61) schizophrenia-like psychosis, [[58]](#cite_note-Vollenweider1998-62) [[59]](#cite_note-Hyde1978-63) and [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion) [[60]](#cite_note-Mack1983-64) have been reported in the literature. A 2005 survey conducted in the United Kingdom found that almost a quarter of those who had used psilocybin mushrooms in the past year had experienced a panic attack. [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9)[ [failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability)] Other adverse effects less frequently reported include paranoia, [confusion](/wiki/Confusion), prolonged [derealization](/wiki/Derealization) (disconnection from reality), and [mania](/wiki/Mania). [[46]](#cite_note-CarhartHarris2010-49) Psilocybin usage can temporarily induce a state of [depersonalization disorder](/wiki/Depersonalization_disorder). [[61]](#cite_note-Simeon2011-65) Usage by those with [schizophrenia](/wiki/Schizophrenia) can induce acute psychotic states requiring hospitalization. [[62]](#cite_note-66) The similarity of psilocybin-induced symptoms to those of schizophrenia has made the drug a useful research tool in behavioral and [neuroimaging](/wiki/Neuroimaging) studies of this psychotic disorder. [[63]](#cite_note-Geyer1998-67) [[64]](#cite_note-Vollenweider2001-68) [[65]](#cite_note-Geyer2008-69) In both cases, psychotic symptoms are thought to arise from a "deficient gating of sensory and cognitive information" in the brain that ultimately lead to "cognitive fragmentation and psychosis". [[64]](#cite_note-Vollenweider2001-68) [Flashbacks](/wiki/Flashback_(psychology)) (spontaneous recurrences of a previous psilocybin experience) can occur long after having used psilocybin mushrooms. [Hallucinogen persisting perception disorder](/wiki/Hallucinogen_persisting_perception_disorder) (HPPD) is characterized by a continual presence of visual disturbances similar to those generated by psychedelic substances. Neither flashbacks nor HPPD are commonly associated with psilocybin usage, [[8]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2011-9) and correlations between HPPD and psychedelics are further obscured by [polydrug and variables. [[66]](#cite_note-Myers1998-70) Tolerance quickly; ingesting psilocybin more than about once a week can lead to diminished effects. Tolerance dissipates after a few days, so doses can be spaced several days apart to avoid the effect. [[68]](#cite_note-Nicholas2006-72) A [cross-tolerance](/wiki/Cross-tolerance) can develop between psilocybin and the pharmacologically similar LSD, [[69]](#cite_note-Passie2008-73) and [phenethylamines](/wiki/Phenethylamine) [mescaline](/wiki/Mescaline) and [DOM](/wiki/2,5-dimethoxy-4-methylamphetamine). [[70]](#cite_note-Halberstadt2011-74) Repeated of psilocybin does not lead to [physical dependence](/wiki/Physical_dependence). [[1]](#cite_note-Passie2002-1) A 2008 study concluded that, based on US data from the period 2000-2002, adolescent-onset (defined here as ages 11-17) usage of hallucinogenic drugs (including psilocybin) did not increase the risk of [drug dependence](/wiki/Substance_dependence) in adulthood; this was in contrast to adolescent usage of [cannabis](/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)), [cocaine](/wiki/Cocaine), [inhalants](/wiki/Inhalant), [anxiolytic](/wiki/Anxiolytic) medicines, and [stimulants](/wiki/Stimulant), all of which were associated with "an excess risk of developing clinical features associated with drug dependence". [[71]](#cite_note-Chen2008-75) Likewise, a 2010 Dutch study ranked the relative harm of psilocybin mushrooms compared to a selection of 19 [recreational drugs](/wiki/Recreational_drugs), including alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, [ecstasy](/wiki/MDMA), [heroin](/wiki/Heroin), and [tobacco](/wiki/Tobacco). Psilocybin mushrooms were ranked as the illicit drug with the lowest harm, [[72]](#cite_note-Amsterdam2010-76) corroborating conclusions reached earlier by expert groups in the United Kingdom. [[73]](#cite_note-Nutt2010-77) Chemistry[ [indole](/wiki/Indole) ring linked to an [aminoethyl](/wiki/Ethylamine) [substituent](/wiki/Substituent). It is structurally related to [serotonin](/wiki/Serotonin), a [monoamine neurotransmitter](/wiki/Monoamine_neurotransmitter) which is a derivative of the [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid) [tryptophan](/wiki/Tryptophan). Psilocybin is a member of the general class of tryptophan-based compounds that originally functioned as [antioxidants](/wiki/Antioxidant) in earlier life forms before assuming more complex functions in multicellular organisms, including humans. However, psilocybin mushrooms have had numerous medicinal [[150]](#cite_note-156) [[151]](#cite_note-157) [[152]](#cite_note-158) and religious uses in [dozens of cultures throughout history](/wiki/Psilocybin_mushroom#Early) and have a significantly lower potential for abuse than other Schedule I drugs. [[153]](#cite_note-159) Psilocybin mushrooms are not regulated by UN treaties. [[154]](#cite_note-160) Many countries, however, have some level of regulation or prohibition of psilocybin mushrooms (for example, the US [Psychotropic Substances Act](/wiki/Psychotropic_Substances_Act_(United_States)), the UK [Misuse of Drugs Act 1971](/wiki/Misuse_of_Drugs_Act_1971), and the Canadian [Controlled Drugs and Substances Act](/wiki/Controlled_Drugs_and_Substances_Act)). [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] In other jurisdictions, they are banned because they are items that are used in drug manufacture. A few jurisdictions (such as the US states of California, Georgia and Idaho) have specifically prohibited the sale and possession of psilocybin mushroom spores. Cultivation of psilocybin mushrooms is considered drug manufacture in most jurisdictions and is often severely penalized, though some countries and one US state (New Mexico) has ruled that growing psilocybin mushrooms does not qualify as "manufacturing" a controlled substance.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Advocacy for tolerance[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=25)] Despite being illegal in many typically Western countries, such as the UK, Australia and some US states, less conservative governments opt to nurture the legal use of psilocybin and other psychedelic drugs. In Amsterdam, Netherlands, authorities provide education and promotion on the safe use of psychedelic drugs, such as psilocybin, in an aim to reduce public harm. [[155]](#cite_note-161) Similarly, religious groups like America's Uniao do Vegetal, UDV, [[156]](#cite_note-Pollan_2018-162) use psychedelics in traditional ceremonies. [[157]](#cite_note-163) From 1st July 2023, the Australian medicines regulator has permitted psychiatrists to prescribe psilocybin for the therapeutic treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. [[158]](#cite_note-164) Advocate for legalization argue there is a lack of evidence of harm, [[159]](#cite_note-165) [[160]](#cite_note-Johansen_2015-166) and potential use in treating certain mental health conditions. Research is difficult to conduct because of the legal status of psychoactive substances. [[161]](#cite_note-Johnson_2018-167) Advocates for legalization also promote the utility of " [ego dissolution](/wiki/Ego_dissolution)" [[156]](#cite_note-Pollan_2018-162) and argue bans are cultural discrimination against traditional users. [[162]](#cite_note-168) Usage[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=26)] A 2009 national survey of drug use by the [US Department of Health and Human Services](/wiki/US_Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services) concluded that the number of first-time psilocybin mushroom users in the United States was roughly equivalent to the number of first-time users of cannabis. [[163]](#cite_note-Bone2011-169) In European countries, the lifetime prevalence estimates of psychedelic mushroom usage among young adults (15-34 years) range from 0.3% to 14.1%. [[164]](#cite_note-EMDCCA2011-170) In modern Mexico, traditional ceremonial use survives among several indigenous groups, including the [Nahuas](/wiki/Nahua_people), the [Matlatzinca](/wiki/Matlatzinca_people), the [Totonacs](/wiki/Totonacs), hallucinogenic Psilocybe species are abundant in low-lying areas of Mexico, most ceremonial use takes places in mountainous areas of elevations greater than 1,500 meters (4,900 ft). [[165]](#cite_note-Guzman2008-171) Current research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Psilocybin&action=edit§ion=27)] Psilocybin has been a subject of clinical research since the early 1960s, when the [Harvard Psilocybin Project](/wiki/Harvard_Psilocybin_Project) evaluated the [potential value of psilocybin](/wiki/Psilocybin_therapy) as a treatment for certain [personality disorders](/wiki/Personality_disorder).
